body:
It was brought to my attention today by Christian Ferreira from MB that ``grdinfo`` fails to report the z min/max values. It turns out that that the grids in question have no **actual_range** but oddly the report is that ``v_min`` and ``v_max`` are zero. Not ``z_min``, ``z_max``.

Example grid can be downloaded from [here](https://cloud.marum.de/s/Yjqyws5BiFbJco3/download?path=%2F&files=gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc&downloadStartSecret=c78i9e62nkq)

So shamelessly GEBCO is not setting the ``actual_range`` attribute and calls ``elevation`` to the ``z`` array. But this is a ``grdinfo ``regression, I think.

```
grdinfo gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: Title: The GEBCO_2021 Grid - a continuous terrain model for oceans and land at 15 arc-second intervals
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: Command: Information on the development of the data set and the source data sets included in the grid can be found in the data set documentation available from https://www.gebco.net
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: Remark:
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: Pixel node registration used [Geographic grid]
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: Grid file format: ns = GMT netCDF format (16-bit integer), CF-1.7
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: x_min: 22.9458333333 x_max: 27.2041666667 x_inc: 0.00416666666667 (15 sec) name: longitude n_columns: 1022
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: y_min: 31.9625 y_max: 35.5041666667 y_inc: 0.00416666666667 (15 sec) name: latitude n_rows: 850
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: v_min: 0 v_max: 0 name: Elevation relative to sea level [m]
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: scale_factor: 1 add_offset: 0
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: format: classic
gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: Default CPT:
```

comments_content.body: No regression, I think.  We have had -M for ages to find data min/max in grdinfo.  We do not loop over the data unless -M is given.
and old 6.2.rc0 gives the same.

And we never crossed with this before? So GEBCO and EMODNET are fscrewing their grids. Because grdinfo may be called in scripts (it is in MB), we should automatically trigger -M when no **actual_range**, no?

But there are tons of reasons why someone might call grdinfo and often knowing the range of z is not one of them.  So we do not want to add that burden unless requested.  Any scripts calling this need to be aware that grids not written by GMT can be fucked.  But GMT grids always writes min/max.

I'm not sure if GEBCO or EMODNET are doing something wrong here. I had a look at the CF Convention (link bellow), and the as I understand in section 4.3 (Vertical (Height or Depth) Coordinate) the default is use V and not Z for the vertical axis. The standard even says: "Optionally, the vertical type may be indicated additionally by providing the standard_name attribute with an appropriate value, and/or the axis attribute with the value Z."

http://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-conventions/cf-conventions-1.9/cf-conventions.html#vertical-coordinate

To me sounds that a grid to be fully compliant with the CF Convention should use V over Z.

Also, if GMT is able to recognise these grids as COARDS, CF-1.5 (under the IDs nb, ns, ni, nf and nd), the same standard was already there in 2010 (link bellow).

http://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-conventions/cf-conventions-1.5/build/cf-conventions.html#vertical-coordinate

Therefore I presume that the use of -M inside grdinfo could perhaps be standard when files are recognised by GMT as COARDS, CF-1.5 (or later), isn't? What are the drawbacks of enabling -M as default for the IDs nb, ns, ni, nf and nd inside GMT?

I dont think  GMT is or will be parsing all possible attributes in a CF file.  However ncdump -h shows this

```
		:geospatial_vertical_min = -10977. ;
		:geospatial_vertical_max = 8685. ;

```
as the only range given for depth.  But this is the global depths for the whole grid.  This particular subset is just

`gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: v_min: -4439 at x = 26.1270833333 y = 34.4354166667 v_max: 2372 at x = 24.03125 y = 35.29375
`

which we get via -M by reading the whole grid.  Looks to me whatever tool wrote this subset did not save the range of this subset's values.  I am not sure we want to force GMT to always read the entire grid file if there is no info on the range since many uses of grdinfo has nothing to do with the range of the data.  But we can have a discussion on this of course.  For instance, if there is no info on the range, perhaps we should turn on -M unless some other option has been selected that implies we do not need the z-range.  And if we had parsed the geospatial_vertical attributes we would have returned the wrong range.

Sorry forgot: The only drawback is that we are forced to read all the values of the grid rather than just the header.  This can take time for very large grids. It is not really noticeable for small files of course, but that is why we have a -M option.

I agree, if the grid "complaint" with the CF convention doesn't follow it and just copy/paste the header of the main GEBCO grid then things get tricky. But I must note that when running grdinfo in the full GEBCO grid I get:

> christian@Christians-MacBook-Pro-2 gebco_2021 % gmt grdinfo GEBCO_2021.nc 
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Title: The GEBCO_2021 Grid - a continuous terrain model for oceans and land at 15 arc-
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Command: Information on the development of the data set and the source data sets included in the grid can be found in the data set documentation available from https://www.gebco.net
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Remark: 
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Pixel node registration used [Geographic grid]
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Grid file format: ns = GMT netCDF format (16-bit integer), CF-1.7
> GEBCO_2021.nc: x_min: -180 x_max: 180 x_inc: 0.00416666666667 (15 sec) name: longitude n_columns: 86400
> GEBCO_2021.nc: y_min: -90 y_max: 90 y_inc: 0.00416666666667 (15 sec) name: latitude n_rows: 43200
> GEBCO_2021.nc: v_min: 0 v_max: 0 name: Elevation relative to sea level [m]
> GEBCO_2021.nc: scale_factor: 1 add_offset: 0
> GEBCO_2021.nc: format: netCDF-4 chunk_size: 0,0 shuffle: off deflation_level: 0
> 
> christian@Christians-MacBook-Pro-2 gebco_2021 % gmt grdinfo GEBCO_2021.nc -M
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Title: The GEBCO_2021 Grid - a continuous terrain model for oceans and land at 15 arc-
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Command: Information on the development of the data set and the source data sets included in the grid can be found in the data set documentation available from https://www.gebco.net
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Remark: 
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Pixel node registration used [Geographic grid]
> GEBCO_2021.nc: Grid file format: ns = GMT netCDF format (16-bit integer), CF-1.7
> GEBCO_2021.nc: x_min: -180 x_max: 180 x_inc: 0.00416666666667 (15 sec) name: longitude n_columns: 86400
> GEBCO_2021.nc: y_min: -90 y_max: 90 y_inc: 0.00416666666667 (15 sec) name: latitude n_rows: 43200
> GEBCO_2021.nc: v_min: -10956 at x = 142.589583333 y = 11.36875 v_max: 8627 at x = 86.9270833333 y = 27.9895833333
> GEBCO_2021.nc: scale_factor: 1 add_offset: 0
> GEBCO_2021.nc: 0 nodes (0.0%) set to NaN
> GEBCO_2021.nc: format: netCDF-4 chunk_size: 0,0 shuffle: off deflation_level: 0
> 

And if I run ncdump on that file the header shows me:

```
	        :geospatial_vertical_min = -10977. ;
		:geospatial_vertical_max = 8685. ;
```

Is it right that grdinfo didn't get that from the netCDF header when not using -M? The file in question is available here: 

[https://www.gebco.net/data_and_products/gridded_bathymetry_data/](https://www.gebco.net/data_and_products/gridded_bathymetry_data/)

PS: I only work with grids up to 4-8GB, and therefore it doesn't bother me much force -M. But I know people working with 3D visualisation using netCDF layers of hundreds of Terabytes. That must be hard if the header is wrong and you're forced to read again the whole file to get the min/max values. That's something I should personally look into since I'm going to work with them this year.

The ``geospatial_vertical_min|max`` are a different story because they are global attributes and ofc we are not going to parse all the global attributes. The problem is that GEBCO and apparently EMODNET are screwing by not inserting the **z** (or whatever name the 2D variable has) **actual_range** attribute. I must confess that I have not GEBCO in high consideration (why the hell do they distribute others grids using their own name?) and if it was only for GEBCO I would say ... But if EMODNET is doing the same shit we may have to do something.

An alternative to Paul's idea, which I don't fully grasp how it would work, is to expand the **-M** option to **-M[f|l]**, where **-Mf**orce (the default for -M) means what it does now and **-Ml**ilght means that if z_range is not given in file then GMT will get it.

BTW, this fails miserably
```
julia> imshow("gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc")
```
![GMTjl_tmp](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/537321/171611756-d7ec8dd7-ed19-4e61-bde2-a9f60f30e2f4.png)

Seems to me the solution is to tell those who write these grids to fix their mistakes and not impose extra solutions for us.  I dont see why it is on us to fix others mistakes.  In the meantime, -M is there to help deal with such grids.  It cannot become a default just because some grids lack proper metadata.

I was not proposing to make it the default. Just to have a *light weight* **-Ml** that could be thrown into scripts that absolutely need to have *z* range but at same time not spending resources and users time when grids are well behaved.
OK, I can see that as a possibility.

If you have time to do this @joa-quim then go ahead.  I would prefer

-M[c|f] for conditional (only if no z-range) or forced [Default]
Note that normal -M affects the output format.  I would think -Mc would only get the min/max (and report them) but not do the rest that -M does (find the location of those min, max).
I'll try but won't have time to look at it before Sunday night.
I'm late to the party but agree that implementing -M[c|f] as described by Paul should let us solve the MB-System problem identified by Christian. Thanks!
@joa-quim I am working on this at the airport.

All tests pass, and that funny grid with **-Mc** now reports

`gebco_2021_n35.50506591796875_s31.96197509765625_w22.9449462890625_e27.2021484375.nc: v_min: -4439 v_max: 2372 name: Elevation relative to sea level [m]
`

Of course, **-Mf** does the same regardless of what the header says, and plain **-M** still means we report the location of the extrema as well.  When the header has a valid range and you use **-Mc** then (with **-Vd**) you can see it skips the read:

`grdinfo [DEBUG]: Found valid actual data range in header - no need to read matrix
`
Still at airports? Well, the good side is that it's good for GMT.

Taking off now

Paul Wessel
Professor, Department of Earth Sciences
(808) 956-4778 | ***@***.***
http://www.soest.hawaii.edu/earthsciences

On June 5, 2022 at 6:12:20 PM, Joaquim ***@***.***) wrote:

> Still at airports? Well, the good side is that it's good for GMT.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/issues/6765#issuecomment-1146892138>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AGJ7IX2CFJCKA5GAQDFOAM3VNUQ4JANCNFSM5XRVXU5Q>
> .
> You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

Thanks a lot  Paul and Joaquim. Dave and I will start testing it and work to adapt the MB-System scripts to the new grdinfo.

PS: I have a few people I know at GEBCO and EMODNET (that seam to care a lot about data quality and compliance to standards) I know and I can report that their grids are written wrong. I don't know if that will produce improvements but I was puzzled that the netCDF grids from these two large entities that was supposed to target GMT users were not GMT/netCDF compatible. But I experienced already that with some crazy netCDF files from Ifremer where everything was scrabbled in GMT, so I used the ESRI ASCII grids that were written properly. I will also contact the CF Convention committee and suggest build a quick test suite to check netCDF grid compliance to CF Conventions, and help spot these mishandling of the standard. Maybe with that would not be always on us to adapt our software to read broken grids.
Thanks Christian. Having them fixing their grids would be the best thing.

title: grdinfo fails to report z_min/max when z var has no *actual_range* attribute
